gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The FGGD land cover occurrence maps are global raster datalayers with a resolution of 5 arc-minutes. Each pixel in each map contains a value representing the percentage of the area belonging to the land cover type concerned. The method is described IIASA, 2007, Mapping biophysical factors that influence agricultural production and rural vulnerability, by H. von Velthuizen et al.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The FGGD Digital Atlas consists of more than 100 global database that allows to analyse food insecurity and poverty in relation to the environment.

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: This dataset is contained in Module 5 "Land use patterns and land cover" of Food Insecurity, Poverty and Environment Global GIS Database (FGGD) (FAO, 2007).

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Forest cover types of the United States and Canada
Fragmentation effects on forest birds: relative influence of woodland cover and configuration on landscape occupancy
A Meta-Analysis of Forest Cover, Edge Effects, and Artificial Nest Predation Rates

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Occurrence of forest - Grid format (1.42 MB)

gmd19157:statement.gco:CharacterString: Landsat-5 multispectral bands (geometrically and radiometrically corrected) are submitted to an automathic classifier that the flooding type of each pixel through a discriminant analysis. The classifier was trained once with images captured during the 2006-2007 season. This information is used to enrich the SIGPAC vector parcel to include for each parcel the flooding types for each date of the season as well as a summary to indicate wheter the field has beef flooded at least on three of the six dates of the season.

gmd19157:description.gco:CharacterString: Geometric correction of Landsat images is carried over images, using ground control points (selected from 1:25000 ortophotomaps). The corrections is based in a first-order polynomial function that takes into account a Digital Elevation Model.

One Landsat-5 image is used for each of the 6 studied dates: 29-10-2006, 14-11-2006, 30-11-2006, 16-12-2006, 17-01-2007 and 22-03-2007. Those dates are selected within the 4 months during the autumn winter period in which the field should be flooded (see "Purpose" metadata element).
DEM 10m

Radiometric correction of Landsat images is based on sensor calibration parameters (extracted from original metadata of the images) and other factors such as atmospheric effects and solar incident angles, taking into account relief. Through this process, digital numbers were converted to reflectance values.
Each of the 5 previous Landsat-5 images after geometric correction.

To focus the study on those rice fields where farmers were applying agrienvironmental measures, as well as to avoid possible spectral confusions with non-desirable classes (e.g. urban areas, roads, forest land), a mask was used.
Each of the 5 previous Landsat-5 images after geometric and radiometric correction.

The mask source was obtained from the vector layer corresponding to the SIGPAC (Agrarian Data Geographic Information Management System) extracting only the agricultural parcels from the original SIGPAC layer containing all land-uses

Discriminant Analysis (DA) involves a linear combination of the original variables to produce a new set of variables that maximize the statistical difference between the predefined groups. DA acts as a standard classifier (applied to each date) because it enables an unknown pixel to be assigned to one of the predefined classes using discriminant functions obtained from a set of training areas. Training areas were obtained from fieldwork carried out in the Ebro Delta on 29 October 2006 and 17 January 2007. Fieldwork was done on two different dates because the class ‘mudflat without water’ does not appear until winter (when the fields begin to dry out). The surface of the training areas collected during fieldwork was 79.7 ha and 40% of them were reserved for an independent test of the results (random sampling).

Training areas collection (47.8 ha): Several sites representative of each class were visited and georeferenced with the aid of a Global Positioning System (Garmin etreX VistaC, Garmin International, Olathe, KS, USA), the cadastre cartography and the most recently available Landsat image.

Test areas collection (31.9 ha): Several sites representative of each class were visited and georeferenced with the aid of a Global Positioning System (Garmin etreX VistaC, Garmin International, Olathe, KS, USA), the cadastre cartography and the most recently available Landsat image.
Each of the 5 previous Landsat-5 images after geometric and radiometric correction and SIGPAC masking

The rustic cadastre vector map (SIGPAC) was enriched with the classification results for each available date. Vector enrichment is a procedure that consists of calculating statistics from a raster image (in our case, a classification image) in the polygon zone of a vector map (in our case, the rustic cadastre cartography). The output of the enrichment is a vector map that is geometrically identical to the input vector map, but contains more alphanumerical information; for example, the majority class in the polygon and the relative surface area occupied by this modal class in the polygon according to the remote sensing raster map. After the rustic cadastre vector cartography is enriched, it can serve as a useful tool for the administrative management of the farmers’ agri-environmental subsidies.
Each of the 5 classifications obtained through the discriminant analysis applied to each of the five Landsat-5 images (after geometric and radiometric correction and SIGPAC masking).

Obtention of the Classification summary: a raster file is obtained from the combination of the five classifications (one for each date) indicating the number of dates when the pixel is flooded (i.e. is labelled as category: deep water, shallow water, ploughed soil with water or mudflat with water). The classification summary raster file values ranging from 0 to 5.

A reclassified map is obtained by classifying each pixel with value 1 when the classification summary value is >=3 and 0 otherwise. The criterium is to consider that if three out of the five dates during the seasin the pixel is flooded, the pixel is considered as compliant with the regulation purposes (i.e. flooded).
Raster classification summary indicating the number of dates when the pixel is flooded.

The final map is obtained by overlaying the binary classification summary to the enriched SIGPAC Parcels. Vector enrichment is a procedure that consists of calculating statistics from a raster image (in this case the binary classification summary: Binary_Classification_summary) in the polygon zone of a vector map (in our case, the enriched SIGPAC parcels: Enriched_SIGPAC_parcels). The output of the enrichment is the vector map that is geometrically identical to the input vector map, that adds to the previous alphanumerical information two new informations for each parcel: 1/ A Yes/No answer to whether the parcel complies with the regulation purposes (i.e. flooded at least three dates), 2/ Purity: relative surface area (percentage) occupied by "Yes" pixels
Binary raster classification summary indicating value 1 when the number of dates when the pixel is flooded is three or more.
Enriched cadastre vector map (SIGPAC) including information of modal class and purity (percentage of parcel surface with the modal class) for each date.

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: Legend issues with South East Asia

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: South East Asia legend mapping: regional classes to GLC2000

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This table gives a full hierarchical mapping from all regional SEA landcover categories to those used in GLC2000

gmd19157:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Validation of the classification using independent test areas (25% of the buffered-MCSC, MCSC_test_12cat source)

gmd19157:samplingScheme.gco:CharacterString: Random sampling with stratification into three lots (all categories included in each of the three lots) (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:lotDescription.gco:CharacterString: Split ground truth buffered-MCSC (MCSC_reclass_buffer) into training subsample (50%, MCSC_train_12cat), test (25%, MCSC_test_12cat) and validation (25%, MCSC_test_test_12cat) subsamples using random stratified sampling methods in R software (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:samplingRatio.gco:CharacterString: 100% of the test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is inspected

gmd19157:valueType.gco:RecordType: Confusion matrix recording counts from ground truthing

gmd19157:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Spatialization of the classification success probability using independent test areas (25% of the buffered-MCSC, MCSC_test_12cat source)

gmd19157:samplingScheme.gco:CharacterString: Random sampling with stratification into three lots (all categories included in each of the three lots) (Stratified_random_sampling process step)

gmd19157:lotDescription.gco:CharacterString: Split ground truth buffered-MCSC (MCSC_reclass_buffer) into training subsample (50%, MCSC_train_12cat), test (25%, MCSC_test_12cat) and validation (25%, MCSC_test_test_12cat) subsamples sing random stratified sampling methods in R software (Stratified_random_sampling process step). The test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is used to define the dependent variable in the logistic regression model: success/failure binomial variable setting a 2 values reclassification of the overlaying of the classification product (ClsMix layer id="LC") and the test ground truth lot (MCSC_test_12cat) i.e., 1=agreement between ClsMix and MCSCtest, 0=disagreement between ClsMix and MCSCtest. Note that the overlaying of the classification product (ClsMix layer) and the test ground truth lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is actually the spatialization of the Confusion Matrix described in the previous quality report.

gmd19157:samplingRatio.gco:CharacterString: 100% of the test lot (MCSC_test_12cat) is inspected. However this procedure implies that only 25% of the ground truth area is used in model fitting and then 10% of this 25% is sampled in the statistical model fitting in order to avoid spatial correlation (still 1105303 pixels analysed)

gmd:attributeDescription.gco:RecordType: This layer is the error model validation layer, i.e. a binomial layer representing coincidence between the values predicted by the logistic regression model and the observed values (either correct/incorrect pixels).
Average success probability for the statistical cluster obtained from linear regression model (object level mean average success probability expressed in %)

gvq:knownProblem.gco:CharacterString: Legend choice is subjective. Some of the original 233 categories have been reclassified as nodata. In the end the % of the MCSC that has been used (with buffering) is 41.38% of the study area. Difficulties in fitting the photointerpretation product legend with a suitable spectral features legend.
